```{r setup, include=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
library(DT)
library(dplyr)
library(pander)

df <- read.csv("https://www.kameronyork.com/datasets/general-conference-talks.csv", encoding = "utf-8")
```

A csv file of all General Conference Talks from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints.  This csv dataset contains the full text and footnotes of all General Conference talks publicly available on churchofjesuschrist.org.  

```{r, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

# Assuming df is your data frame
# Filter only numeric columns for histograms
numeric_columns <- sapply(df, is.numeric)
numeric_column_names <- names(df)[numeric_columns]

for (column_name in numeric_column_names) {
  p <- ggplot(df, aes_string(x=column_name)) + 
    geom_histogram(bins=30, fill="blue", color="black") + 
    theme_minimal()
  
  # Save the histogram as an image
  ggsave(paste0(column_name, "_hist.png"), plot=p, width=5, height=3, dpi=300)
}

# For a categorical column example
if ("your_categorical_column_name" %in% names(df)) {
  p <- ggplot(df, aes_string(x="your_categorical_column_name")) + 
    geom_bar(fill="blue", color="black") + 
    theme_minimal()
  
  ggsave("your_categorical_column_name_bar.png", plot=p, width=5, height=3, dpi=300)
}
```

## Column Distribution Histograms

```{r echo=FALSE, results='asis'}
library(knitr)
# Assuming the images are saved in the working directory
for (column_name in column_names) {
  cat('![](', column_name, '_hist.png)', sep='')
  cat('\n')
}

# Display the table
kable(df)
```

This code chunk uses a loop to embed each histogram image above your table. The `kable` function from the `knitr` package is used to create a simple Markdown table from your data frame.

### Notes

- Ensure all histogram images are saved in the same directory as your Rmd file or specify the correct path to them.
- Adjust the `width`, `height`, and `dpi` in `ggsave` to fit your needs.
- This approach creates static images. If your data updates and you rerun the Rmd file, the histograms will update based on the current data.

This method provides a basic way to include column distribution histograms in an R Markdown document. For more dynamic or interactive options, you might explore embedding HTML widgets or Shiny applications, although these may require a more complex setup.
